title: YUKO SHIMIZU: CONTEMPORARY HEROINES
media_alt:
Yuko Shimizu, illustration for cover and products: ãƒžã‚­ã‚·ãƒžãƒ ãƒ»ã‚¶ãƒ»ãƒ›ãƒ«ãƒ¢ãƒ³ (Maximum the Hormone) (Japanese metal band) 
DVD Deka Vs Deka (Nov 2015 released)
references: Yuko Shimizu, contemporary art theory
body_md:
YUKO SHIMIZU: CONTEMPORARY HEROINES

How to combine Japanese and American illustration?

â€œWhat makes so interesting the illustrations of Yuko Shimizu, that many clients around the world has been hiring her to illustrate their posters for events and covers of magazines, albums and books?

This episode of Contemporary Art Theory, studies the art of this Japanese Illustrator based in New York.

(Introduction)
The overall experience of a Yuko Shimizu artwork is always a fully immersive world. It has a story within a specific scenario and consequently we can study each one of her artworks like we analyze movies.
There are three elements that help the artist to achieve this cinematic effect: The characters, the ambient and the technique.

1. The Characters:
In Yukoâ€™s art,
1)      There is always a main character with a CLEAR FACIAL EXPRESSION: for example he or she is suffering, enduring, yielding, struggling, stretching or searching for something. In other words, there is always emotion and it is clear that the character is taking a side in an event.  
2)      This is also supported by the fact that the character is in the middle of an action, he or she is DOING something, whether it is jumping, kicking, swimming or contemplating.
3)      The character is always portrayed from an unusual angle. Very rarely is a frontal view of a standing person as we see in our everyday lives. There are often tilt-up and tilt-down angles to emphasize dramatism in the composition and set the viewer as a particular witness.

2. The Ambient.
4)      There are always many volatile objects that give the scene a feeling of frozen gravity and multidirectional weight. â€“ There is constantly a signature collective behavior in those objects but very often, each one has a story to tell. For example arrows are flying around but some of them are broken or smashed. Birds are in the air but each one in a different moment of his flying process. This gives the composition the complementary sensation of variety within a unity.
5)      The environment plays a meaningful role because it is active. Either if it is fire, air, like in a strong wind or Water (in all different presentations like snow, splash drops, rain, clouds, waves). The elements are always present and always in movement.
6)      In Yukoâ€™s artworks, Cultural icons are being revisited. So you know you are looking at a specific cultural reference, but now in a different context and with a different intention. So the spectator tends to look for new meanings and clues to experience the tradition in a contemporary way.

3. The Technique:
The feeling of the hand-drawing is protagonist. The strong silhouettes also give us a clear clue on the tradition of comic illustration.
8)      The texture of the paper is also present to create a warm sensation, like in a documentary film.
The grading and vignette effects also help to generate a nostalgic image. The same happens when we discover beautiful illustrations in old books or watch shorts images from the first movies ever made.  

As an overall conclusion:
9)      And finally looking at the illustrations all together, in Yuko Shimizuâ€™s portfolio: The viewer getâ€™s the impression of proactive lives. There is never a feeling of coward neutrality or passiveness. These are the new types of heroes from which we would like to know more about, follow and join in their adventures.

title: Blindness
references: Jose Saramago, Blindness
body_md:
BLINDNESS

I know the reason why you hate so much this kind of place,
and I know why you feel so proudful to look at nobody,
but which kind of happiness lies under obliviousness?
Spending your time avoiding any other human gaze.

It's because you don't want to feel bothered
by the gaze of any stranger
staring at your straight in to your eyes.
That's ehy you don't take your eyes out of your
radio-tv-pc-phone-visor,
it's the white blindness described by Saramago.

If we both make faces like animals,
trapped in urban traffic lights,
and it is our perpetual reality,
to be connections, weirder every time. 

Everything to fool yourself,
about your lightweight pleasantness, 
and dettach your 'bright future' from this current time
that is always confrontational.

keywords: self-destructive behavior, obsessive-compulsive disorder, hoarding disorder
references: self-destructive behavior, obsessive-compulsive disorder, hoarding disorder
body_md:
SELF-DESTRUCTIVE

Your portraits are getting outdated
in the social network you used to check yourself.
And it will be pointless,
that you got minions of followers robots.

Your anxiety to get every time more,
the skin of the world will dissolve.
Obsessive compulsive disorder:
Self-destructive behavior.

You rip off the land, 
exploit and kill living beings of all kinds.
Desperate for the latest collectibles,
accumulating you will not fill your existencial emptyness.

title: Trigger
keywords: emotional triggers, hot buttons, emotional flooding, perpetual problems, reactive cycle, attachment injuries, threats
references: Emotional triggers, Hot buttons, Emotional flooding, perpetual problems, reactive cycle, attachment injuries, threats
body_md:
TRIGGER

Pain, has many names,
emotions attached to piercing memories.
Releasing free radicals,
scenes from the past that grow present spikes.

Trigger, triggers
a word away from shouting,
trigger the animal,
we're actively endorsing tragedies.

Bigger triggers, triggers everywhere,
unable to stop the escalating mess,
bigger triggers and reasons to ignite.
Rage hiddes behind every other thing.

Don't wait "for the pain to make sense".
